reason.tex: %text The line representing the shortest distance between any two Skew (non-intersecting and not parallel) lines is perpendicular to both the lines. %

options.tex: %text The shortest distance between the two lines is given by % \begin{align} \left[(\vector{3}{5}{7})-(\vector{-1}{-1}{-1})\right]\cdot \hat n_\perp \end{align}\\ %text where $n_\perp$ is the unit vector perpendicular to both lines. %

%text The shortest distance between the two lines is given by % \begin{align} \left[(\vector{3}{5}{7})-(\vector{-1}{-1}{-1})\right]\cdot \hat n_\perp \end{align}\\ %text where $n_\perp$ is the unit vector perpendicular to both lines. %

reason.tex: %text If $\ora{r}=\ora{a_1}+\lambda\ora{b_1}$ and $\ora{r}=\ora{a_2}+\lambda\ora{b_2}$ are two lines then they each pass through $\ora{a_1}$ and $\ora{a_2}$ respectively, $(\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})$ is their displacement vector. However, the shortest distance $d$ is the projection of $(\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})$ along the $\perp$ to both lines. Therefore, % \begin{align} d&=(\ora{a_2}-\ora{a_1})\cdot\left(\dfrac{\ora{b_1}\times\ora{b_2}}{|\ora{b_1}\times \ora{b_2|}}\right) \\ &=\left[(\vector{3}{5}{7})-(\vector{-1}{-1}{-1})\right]\cdot \hat n_\perp \end{align}\\
